values.alignmentText: Montreal, QC: bilingual CRA/Québec filings; ~40-60h/yr with a fractional accountant; aligns with a family seeking simpler tax processes.

- CAD 1,200,000.00 ($900,000.00) – CIPVG – Quebec’s refundable tax credit for video game production; supports Quebec payroll costs and salaries for eligible staff, making it feasible to staff a 2-year project.
- CAD 350,000.00 ($262,500.00) – SODEC IDM Development – Aide au développement de projets IDM; provides early-stage grants to develop narrative-driven interactive works in Quebec with evaluation based on artistic merit and market potential.
- CAD 250,000.00 ($187,500.00) – CMF IDM Production – Canada Media Fund – Offers co-investment for digital media games; supports prototyping/production with cash or in-kind, and requires Canadian ownership/commercial viability.
- CAD 100,000.00 ($75,000.00) – Mitacs Accelerate – R&D Internship Funding – Provides stipends for interns to work on game development projects through university partnerships, reducing payroll costs during critical phases.
- CAD 75,000.00 ($56,250.00) – CALQ – Creation and Production – Conseil des Arts et des Lettres du Québec – Funds independent project creation/production with emphasis on artistic quality and local language; supports small teams with targeted grants.

Montreal/Quebec immigration status and rights: you can enter with a temporary permit (visitor, work, or study) and then pursue permanent residency (PR) via federal Express Entry or the Quebec-selected Skilled Worker (CSQ) route; in Quebec, CSQ is often needed before federal PR. Once PR is granted, you and your family gain broad rights to work and study in Canada and access to universal healthcare (Quebec enrollment). Citizenship rights accrue after meeting PR residence requirements and language/civics tests (typically 3 of the last 5 years as a PR and passing knowledge tests). Actionable steps: choose a Montreal-ready pathway (CSQ-first or federal Express Entry), gather documents (passports, education/work records, credential assessments, language tests), pursue French to improve Quebec prospects, apply for PR, maintain residency and status renewals, and plan for eventual citizenship; consider consulting an immigration professional to tailor the path to your family’s profile and Quebec-specific requirements.
